source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubes were cold worked to three different levels: 18, 30, and 35%. They were then autoclaved at 425°C for 72 h. The autoclave film thickness was 2 to 4 μm.
process_step: cold working, autoclaving at 425°C for 72 h

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk1
evidence_span: Despite the differences in metallurgical condition, there are some similarities in the effects of radiation on the microstructure. In the early material, which was beta quenched and aged (with some intermediate cold work), irradiation produced additional βNb precipitation along twin boundaries in the α'Zr structure... For the cold-worked material described here, irradiation is seen to have caused precipitation of βNb precipitates within the elongated alpha Zr grains
specimen_state: beta quenched and aged (with intermediate cold work); cold-worked
process_step: beta quenching, aging, cold working, irradiation

extra_properties.microstructural_changes: βNb precipitation along twin boundaries in α'Zr structure (early material); βNb precipitation within elongated alpha Zr grains (cold-worked material)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk2
evidence_span: In CANDU reactors the theoretical uptake from waterside corrosion is in the range of 30 to 60% for Zr2 pressure tubes, whereas for all Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes, except Tube P3L09, the calculated uptake fraction is generally in the low end of the range 5 to 20%

evidence_span: G. P. Sabol (Westinghouse)—I am most impressed with this new experimental data, but the previous paper indicates a solubility limit of iron below that find of $0 . 0 4 \%$ . Also, their thermoelectric rate data indicate relatively rapid attainment of equilibrium in the matrix. Can you rationalize your data with that of the previous paper?

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk12
evidence_span: B. Wadman-—(1) The anodic oxide layer is field evaporated away at a specimen temperature of $9 0 ~ \bf K$ . The evaporation process is monitored by neon field ion microscopy.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk12
evidence_span: B. Wadman—Because of the low noise level (high signal-to-noise ratio) and the high mass resolution $( \mathbf { F W H M } < 1 / 5 0 0 )$ all signals at correct mass-to-charge ratios are considered significant. The statistical accuracy is approximately given by the standard deviation of the binomial distribution. For a small number of ions $N$ this is simply $\sqrt { N }$ .

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk12
evidence_span: G. M. Hood—In terms of the work that we have done to date the reprecipitation phenomenon does seem to take place on a time scale that is consistent with our data for iron spacer diffusion in alpha-Zr.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk12
evidence_span: G. M. Hood—In our measurements the tracer $^ { 5 9 } \mathrm { F e }$ concentration is trivial compared to the residual iron in the specimens (either as an impurity or present deliberately as in ZrFe alloy). I do not recall seeing an effect, such as you mention, probably because the "Fe concentration is relatively uniform" across the specimen.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk13
evidence_span: G. M. Hood-(1) The only data I know of for $D _ { \mathfrak { n } }$ and $D _ { \perp }$ for self diffusion is in our 1974 Acta Met Paper, $D _ { \parallel } { \sim } 1 . 1 \times D _ { \perp } ?$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_046_chunk13
evidence_span: nickel in pure zirconium is, intrinsically, an ultra-fast diffusor $( D \sim 0 ^ { - 1 0 } ~ \mathrm { { m ^ { 2 } s ^ { - 1 } } }$ at $8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$
